episode_title: 203 - The One Where Mr. Heckles Dies

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, everyone except Chandler is playing poker.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hey.

content.speaker: All
content.text: Hey!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: So how was Joan?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I broke up with her.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Don’t tell me, because of the big nostril thing?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: They were huge. When she sneezed, bats flew out of them.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Come on, they were not that huge.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I’m tellin’ you, she leaned back; I could see her brain.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: How many perfectly fine women are you gonna reject over the most superficial insignificant things?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hold it, hold it. I gotta side with Chandler on this one. When I first moved to the city, I went out a couple of times with this girl, really hot, great kisser, but she had the biggest Adam’s apple. It made me nuts.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You or me?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: I got it. Uh, Joey, women don’t have Adam’s apples.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: You guys are messing with me, right?

content.speaker: All
content.text: Yeah.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: That was a good one. For a second there, I was like, “whoa.”

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, Phoebe is getting Ross and Chandler a beer.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: You name one woman that you broke up with for a real reason.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Maureen Rosilla.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: “’Cause she doesn’t hate Yanni,” is not a real reason.
(There’s a knock on the door.)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Hello, Mr. Heckles.

content.speaker: Mr. Heckles
content.text: You’re doing it again.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: We’re not doing anything.

content.speaker: Mr. Heckles
content.text: You’re stomping. It’s disturbing my birds.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You don’t have birds.

content.speaker: Mr. Heckles
content.text: I could have birds.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Okay, Mr. Heckles, we’ll try to keep it down.

content.speaker: Mr. Heckles
content.text: Thank you. I’m going to rejoin my dinner party.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: All right, bye-bye.
(Monica closes the door.)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Okay, Janice. Janice. You gotta give me Janice. That wasn’t about being picky.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: We’ll give you Janice.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I miss Janice though. (Imitating Janice) “Hello, Chandler Bing.”

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: “Oh, my, god.”

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: “Oh, Chandler, now, now, that’s it. There, faster!” (He turns around and everyone is staring at him.)
(Mr. Heckles bangs on his ceiling.)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Stop with the broom, we’re not making noise.
(She stomps in protest. Heckles bangs again, which is answered by Monica and Rachel. Heckles bangs yet again, which is answered by everyone. There is no response.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: We won. We won!
[Cut to a man wrapped up on a sheet being wheeled out on a gurney with the gang and Mr. Treeger looking on.]

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Mr. Heckles.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: How did this happen?

content.speaker: Mr. Treeger
content.text: He musta been sweeping. They found a broom in his hand.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: That’s terrible.

content.speaker: Mr. Treeger
content.text: I know. I was sweeping yesterday. It coulda been me.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Sure, you coulda. You never know.

content.speaker: Mr. Treeger
content.text: You never know.

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, the next day everyone is eating dinner.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ok, it’s very faint, but I can still sense him in the building. (Screaming) Go into the light, Mr. Heckles!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Ok, Phoebe.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I’m sorry, but sometimes they need help. (Everyone groans) That’s fine. Go ahead and scoff. You know there’re a lot of things that I don’t believe in, but that doesn’t mean they’re not true.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Such as?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Like crop circles, or the Bermuda triangle, or evolution?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. What, you don’t, uh, you don’t believe in evolution?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Nah. Not really.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You don’t believe in evolution?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I don’t know, it’s just, you know…monkeys, Darwin, you know, it’s a, it’s a nice story, I just think it’s a little too easy.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Too easy? Too…The process of every living thing on this planet evolving over millions of years from single-celled organisms, is-is too easy?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Yeah, I just don’t buy it.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Uh, excuse me. Evolution is not for you to buy, Phoebe. Evolution is scientific fact, like, like, like the air we breathe, like gravity.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ok, don’t get me started on gravity.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You uh, you don’t believe in gravity?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Well, it’s not so much that you know, like I don’t believe in it, you know, it’s just…I don’t know, lately I get the feeling that I’m not so much being pulled down as I am being pushed.
(There’s a knock on the door.)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Uh-Oh. It’s Isaac Newton, and he’s pissed.
(Monica opens the door.)

content.speaker: Mr. Treeger
content.text: There she is. And over there, that’s the other one. This is Mr. Buddy Boyle, Mr. Heckles’ attorney. He’d like to talk to you.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: What can we do for you?

content.speaker: Mr. Boyle
content.text: All right, kids. Here’s the deal. According to my client’s will, he wants to leave all his earthly possessions to “The noisy girls in the apartment above mine.”

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Well, what about his family?

content.speaker: Mr. Boyle
content.text: He didn’t have any.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Ok, so let’s talk money.

content.speaker: Mr. Boyle
content.text: All right, there was none. Let’s talk signing. (To Monica) You be noisy girl number one, (To Rachel) you be noisy girl number two.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: I can’t believe that this whole time we thought he hated us. I mean, isn’t it amazing how much you can touch someone’s life, without even knowing it?

content.description: Mr. Heckles’ apartment, the gang is looking over Monica and Rachel’s inheritance.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Would you look at this dump? He hated us. This is his final revenge!

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Have you ever seen so much crap?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Actually, I think this apartment sullies the good name of crap

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Check this out. Can I have this? (It’s a giant magnifying glass on a stand.)
[Cut to Phoebe and Ross.]

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: How can you not believe in evolution?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Just don’t. Look at this funky shirt!

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Pheebs, I have studied evolution my entire adult life. Ok, I can tell you, we have collected fossils from all over the world that actually show the evolution of different species, ok? You can literally see them evolving through time.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Really? You can actually see it?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You bet. In the U.S., China, Africa, all over.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: See, I didn’t know that.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Well, there you go.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Huh. So now, the real question is, who put those fossils there, and why?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hey, look at this. “My Big Book of Grievances.”

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey, there’s me! April 17th. Excessive noise. Italian guy comes homes with a date. Hey Chandler, look, you’re in here too.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: April 18th, excessive noise. Italian guy’s gay roommate comes home with the dry-cleaning. Well that’s excellent.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Monica, Monica, look at this lamp. (She’s holding a lamp made from seashells.) Is this tacky or what? We have to have this.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Rache, I think we have enough regular lamps.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What? Come on, it’s not like I’m asking for this girlie clock or anything, which, by the way, I also think is very cool. (It’s a girl in a bikini and pasties standing behind an alarm clock.)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: It doesn’t go with any of my stuff.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well, what about my stuff?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: You don’t have any stuff.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You still think of it as your apartment, don’t you?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: No.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yes you do. You think of it as your apartment, and I’m just somebody who rents a room.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Mmmmm.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Ok, while you “mmm” on it for awhile, I’m gonna go find a place for my new lamp.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ok, Pheebs. (He’s holding two little toys.) See how I’m making these little toys move? Opposable thumbs. Without evolution, how do you explain opposable thumbs?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Maybe the overlords needed them to steer their spacecrafts.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Please tell me you’re joking.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Look, can’t we just say that you believe in something, and I don’t.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: No, no, Pheebs, we can’t, ok, because—

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: What is this obsessive need you have to make everyone agree with you? No, what’s that all about? I think, I think maybe it’s time you put Ross under the microscope.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Is there blood coming out of my ears?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Check it out, check it out. Heckles’ high school yearbook.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Wow, he looks so normal.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: He’s even kind of cute.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: “Heckles, you crack me up in science class. You’re the funniest kid in school.”

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Funniest? Heckles?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: That’s what it says.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Wow, Heckles was voted class clown, and so was I. (There’s a banging coming from upstairs.) He was right. Would you listen to that?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I’d call that excessive.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Whoa!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Heckles played clarinet in band, and I played clarinet. And he was in the scale modeler’s club, and I was, well, there was no club, but I sure thought they were cool.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: So, you were both dorks. Big deal.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I just think it’s weird, you know? (The banging is back.) Heckles and me, Heckles, and me, me and Heckles… (He picks up the broom and bangs on the ceiling) Would you knock it off? (Everyone stares) (Realizes) Bah! (He throws the broom down.)

content.description: Mr. Heckles’ Apartment, Chandler is in one of Heckles’ old robes and sitting on the couch.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Have you been here all night?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Look at this. Pictures of all the women that Heckles went out with. Look what he wrote on them. (As he mentions each name and description, he hands a picture to Joey.) Vivian, too tall. Madge, big gums. Too loud, too smart, makes noise when she eats. This is, this is me. This is what I do. I’m gonna end up alone, just like he did.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Chandler, Heckles was a nut case.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Our trains are on the same track, ok? Yeah, sure, I’m coming up 30 years behind him, but the stops are all the same. Bitter Town. Aloneville. Hermit Junction.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: All right, you know what we gotta do? We gotta get you outta here. Come on, I’ll buy you breakfast, let’s go.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: What if I never find someone? Or worse, what if I’ve found her, but I dumped her because she pronounced it ‘supposably?’

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Chandler, come on, you’re gonna find somebody.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: How do you know that? How?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: I don’t know, I’m just tryin’ to help you out.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You’ll see, you guys are all gonna go off and get married, and I’m gonna end up alone. Will you promise me something? When you’re married, will you invite me over for holidays?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Well, I don’t know. I don’t know what we’re gonna be doin’. I mean, what if we’re at her folks’ place?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yeah, I understand.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: You can come over and watch the Super Bowl. Every year, all right?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You know what? I’m not gonna end up like this. I’ll see you man.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Supposably. Supposably. Did they go to the zoo? Supposably.

content.description: Chandler and Joey’s, Chandler enters, picks up the phone, and dials.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hi, it’s me.

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Oh, my, god.

content.description: Central Perk, Chandler is telling everyone about his phone call.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Janice? You called Janice?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yes, Janice. Why is that so difficult for you to comprehend?

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You remember Janice, right?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yes. She was smart, she was pretty, and she honestly cared about me. Janice is my last chance to have somebody.

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Helloo!!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Oh…my…God!

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Geez, look how fat she got.

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Hey, it’s everybody.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Janice, you’re…

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Yes, I am.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Is it…

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Is it yours? Ha! You wish, Chandler Bing. You are looking at a married lady now. (She shows everyone her ring.)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Congratulations.

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: Oh, sweetie, I’m sorry.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: You couldn’t have told me about this on the phone?

content.speaker: Janice
content.text: And what? Missed the expression on your face? Janice likes to have her fun.

content.description: Monica and Rachel’s, Rachel is reading and admiring her new lamp.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Hey, Rache. You know what we haven’t played in a while?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Hide the Lamp.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Monica, let it go.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Did you know I was allergic to shellfish?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Well, then, you’ll just have to eat the other lamps.
(Ross enters carrying a briefcase.)

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Uh-oh. It’s Scary Scientist Man.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: Ok, Phoebe, this is it. In this briefcase I carry actual scientific facts. A briefcase of facts, if you will. Some of these fossils are over 200 million years old.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ok, look, before you even start, I’m not denying evolution, ok, I’m just saying that it’s one of the possibilities.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: It’s the only possibility, Phoebe.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ok, Ross, could you just open your mind like this much, ok? (Holding her thumb and forefinger close together) Wasn’t there a time when the brightest minds in the world believed that the world was flat? And, up until like what, 50 years ago, you all thought the atom was the smallest thing, until you split it open, and this like, whole mess of crap came out. Now, are you telling me that you are so unbelievably arrogant that you can’t admit that there’s a teeny tiny possibility that you could be wrong about this? (Monica and Rachel are intrigued.)

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: There might be…a teeny…tiny…possibility.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: I can’t believe you caved.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: What?

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: You just abandoned your whole belief system. I mean, before, I didn’t agree with you, but at least I respected you. How, how, how are you going to go into work tomorrow? How, how are you going to face the other science guys? How, how are you going to face yourself? (Ross slowly closes the briefcase and walks out hugging it.) Oh! That was fun. So who’s hungry?

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: I am. Let me just get my coat.
(As Monica puts on her coat she knocks over and breaks the seashell lamp.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What happened?! What happened?!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Ok, all right. It was an accident, I swear, all right. I was putting on my jacket, and the thing, and the lamp, and it broke.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Oh, please, Monica. You’ve always hated my lamp, and then, all of a sudden, it’s just magically broken?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Phoebe, tell her!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Ok, I didn’t see it, because I was putting on my jacket, but I uh want to believe you.
(Chandler enters.)

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Hey Chandler. Monica just broke my seashell lamp.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Neat. I’m gonna die alone.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Ok, you win.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Chandler, you’re not gonna die alone.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Janice was my safety net, ok? And now I have to get a snake.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Uh huh. Why is that?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: If I’m gonna be an old, lonely man, I’m gonna need a thing, you know, a hook, like that guy on the subway who eats his own face. So I figure I’ll be Crazy Man with a Snake, y’know. Crazy Snake Man. And I’ll get more snakes, call them my babies, kids will walk past my place, they will run. “Run away from Crazy Snake Man,” they’ll shout!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: You have got to get over this. You’re not gonna end up alone.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Of course I am. I reject anyone who’s crazy enough to actually go out with me, and then I bitch about the fact that there aren’t any great women out there.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Chandler, you have just described virtually every man that we have ever gone out with.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: You are not a freak. You’re a guy.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: She’s right. She’s right. You are no different than the rest of them.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Wait a minute, wait a minute. Yes he is. You are totally different.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: In a bad way?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: No, honey, in a wonderful way. You know what you want now. Most guys don’t even have a clue. You are ready to take risks, you are ready to be vulnerable, and intimate with someone.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Yeah. You’re not gonna end up alone.

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: Chandler, you called Janice! That’s how much you wanted to be with someone!

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: You made it!

content.speaker: Phoebe
content.text: You’re there!

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: You are ready to make a commitment!

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Whoa! Don’t know about that.

content.description: Mr. Heckles’ Apartment, everyone is finishing cleaning up the apartment as Monica walks up to Rachel carrying the girlie clock.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: What you got there? Something else that’s not yours that you can break?

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: No. Um, I know you like this, and I want you to have it. I think it’ll look good in our apartment.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: Thank you.
(The clock sounds it’s alarm by whistling and having the girl shake her hips.)

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: That’s fine.

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Hey. Well, you will all be pleased to know that I have a date tomorrow night. This woman Alison, from work, she’s great. She’s pretty. She’s smart. And uh, I’ve been holding off on asking her out in the past, because she has an unusually large head. But, I’m not gonna let that stuff hang me up anymore. Look at me. I’m growing.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Hey, uh, you can’t recycle yearbooks, can you?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: I’ll take that.

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: You want his yearbook?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yeah, yeah. Some people said some nice things about him. I think somebody should have it.

content.speaker: Monica
content.text: Oh, gosh, this is so weird. I mean, his whole life was in this apartment, and now it’s gone. You know, I think it would be nice if we just took a few moments, for Mr. Heckles. I mean, he was kind of a pain, he was, but he was a person. (She ends up standing behind the magnifying glass and everyone is laughing.) (Realizes.)You’re all going to hell.

content.speaker: Rachel
content.text: It’s really not that big!
(Joey grabs the magnifying glass and walks out.)

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Takin’ that with you, huh?

content.speaker: Joey
content.text: Oh, yeah.

content.speaker: Ross
content.text: You comin’?

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Yeah, just second. (Ross exits and Chandler picks up the broom and leans it up against the wall.) Good-bye Mr. Heckles. (He turns off the lights.) We’ll try to keep it down.

content.description: A Restaurant, Chandler is on his date with Allison.

content.speaker: Allison
content.text: Oh, my major was totally useless. I mean, how often do you look in the classifieds and see “Philosopher wanted?”

content.speaker: Chandler
content.text: Sure. (In his head.) My god, that’s a big head! It didn’t look this big in the office. Maybe it’s the lighting. My head must look like a golf ball at work. All right, don’t get hung up on it, quick, quick, list five things you like about her: Nice smile, good dresser…Big head, big head, big head !
